resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading, adopting it based on Articles 33, 114, and 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the Commission’s 2013 legislative proposal (COM(2013)0075), which aimed to harmonize internal market rules and trade policies. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on International Trade, as outlined in report A7-0346/2013, and considered the European Economic and Social Committee’s May 2013 opinion. It urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending substantial amendments and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU legal frameworks and procedural accountability.

title: Measuring instruments: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States relating to making available on the market of measuring instruments (recast)
background: Following the 2008 political agreement on goods regulation and the Lisbon Treaty’s revised legislative framework, the European Commission proposed recasting directives to harmonize technical rules for market access. The Parliament will discuss aligning member states’ laws on measuring instruments’ market availability under the new legislative framework, ensuring updated EU internal market standards.

stances.stance:
SD strongly promotes the enhanced market surveillance provisions, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to consumer safety and eliminating dangerous non-compliant products from the single market.  
SD approves the bureaucratic reduction measures in Articles 4-7 as effectively advancing SD's priority of creating a transparent business environment with harmonized technical standards.  
SD proposes enhancing Annex II through regular verification mechanisms for dual-use explosive materials to prevent misuse, while fully endorsing the directive's core harmonization framework.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on parliamentary oversight in recital 9, which matches SD's 2023 manifesto commitment to institutional accountability in technical legislation.  
SD strongly promotes the consolidated legal framework as critical for maintaining fair competition between EU manufacturers and third-country producers.

ECR strongly upholds the harmonization of measuring instrument laws under Article 114 TFEU, aligning perfectly with their commitment to regulatory clarity and single market efficiency through codification without substantive changes.  
ECR applauds the issue’s modernization of consumer-facing information requirements, effectively advancing electronic accessibility and transparency as cornerstones of their consumer protection agenda.  
ECR highlights the opportunity to strengthen interinstitutional cooperation by proposing structured consultation frameworks for delegated acts, ensuring Member State concerns are addressed while upholding Lisbon Treaty principles.  
ECR underscores the necessity of safeguarding Parliament’s prerogatives in comitology working groups, urging the Commission to formalize parliamentary oversight to prevent procedural bottlenecks and enhance trust.  
ECR emphasizes the importance of renewed interinstitutional agreements to clarify delegation dynamics, ensuring future legislation balances Commission discretion with collaborative governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0769) to codify existing legislation under Article 114 of the TFEU, confirming that the text constitutes a straightforward codification without substantive changes to previous acts, as verified by the Consultative Working Party of the EU legal services. It emphasized the importance of maintaining legal clarity by consolidating unchanged provisions and previously identified amendments into a single coherent act. The resolution called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if it intends to introduce substantial revisions, ensuring parliamentary oversight. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring adherence to procedural transparency and interinstitutional cooperation.

title: Internal Market Scoreboard: REPORT on the Internal Market Scoreboard
background: The European Commission monitors Member States' transposition of internal market directives, with persistent transposition delays and market fragmentation affecting cross-border economic activities. The Parliament will discuss measures to enhance the internal market's functionality through improved legislative implementation and enforcement mechanisms.

stances.stance:
ALDE fully supports the issue’s emphasis on strengthening SOLVIT centers, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to reducing bureaucratic barriers for SMEs through rapid, pragmatic dispute issue.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for an “internal-market test” to safeguard legislative integrity, reflecting their manifesto priority of preventing fragmented market rules that disadvantage cross-border enterprises.  
ALDE fully supports the annual Internal Market Forum proposal, recognizing it as essential to advancing their goal of systematic best-practice sharing between Member States and EU institutions.  
ALDE strongly approves consolidating market information into the ‘Your Europe – Business’ portal, a measure that directly advances their advocacy for streamlined SME access to cross-border opportunities.  
ALDE fully supports the issue’s focus on consumer education and collective redress mechanisms, highlighting the critical need for a European model of class action to reinforce trust in cross-border transactions.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's reliance on unregulated competition as a driver of prosperity, entirely challengeing with their principle that market mechanisms fail to protect vulnerable consumers without price controls on essential goods.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Internal Market Scoreboard's numerical performance metrics, which overlook critical aspects like quantifiable social targets and wealth redistribution to address systemic inequality.  
GUE_NGL condemns the "internal-market test" proposal as inherently prioritizing corporate interests over public welfare, inconsistent with their demand for legislation centered on human needs rather than market integrity.  
GUE_NGL challenges the assumption that administrative burden reduction benefits citizens, arguing it weakens safeguards against corporate profiteering and deregulation of worker protections.  
GUE_NGL dismisses the issue’s consumer confidence framework as inadequate, emphasizing that true security requires binding price caps and anti-speculation measures absent from the text.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for Member States to fully implement all measures under the Commission’s 2009 Recommendation to improve the single market, avoiding selective adoption. It urged closer collaboration between Member States, the Commission, and stakeholders to enforce internal market rules effectively, reduce administrative burdens, and address transposition deficits through early dialogue, information exchange, and support during transposition. The resolution emphasized involving national parliaments, social partners, and regional authorities in legislative processes to ensure correct transposition and implementation, critical for market functionality, competition, and stability. It called for an annual Internal Market Forum (with working and ministerial-level meetings) to share best practices and strengthen commitment to enforcement. The Parliament stressed enhancing the Internal Market Scoreboard with detailed enforcement data, objective indicators, and synchronized annual publication alongside SOLVIT, Consumer Market Scoreboard, and Citizens Signpost reports to provide a comprehensive market overview. It advocated for an "internal-market test" to prevent new legislation from undermining market integrity, improved legislative quality via impact assessments, and ex-post evaluations to assess effectiveness. Member States were urged to provide detailed transposition data via correlation tables, boost SOLVIT resources for dispute resolution, and increase visibility of its services. The resolution highlighted consolidating fragmented market information into the 'Your Europe - Business' portal as a one-stop-shop, leveraging the Enterprise Europe Network to support SMEs while reducing bureaucratic hurdles, and ensuring regular training for civil servants on internal market rules.

title: Internal market for services: REPORT on the Internal Market for Services: State of Play and Next Steps
background: The European Union’s services sector, representing over 65% of GDP and employment, faced persistent barriers to cross-border provision, uneven implementation of the 2006 Services Directive, and administrative complexities affecting market integration. The Parliament will discuss progress and challenges in harmonizing the internal market for services under existing EU legislation.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's exclusive focus on service sector liberalization while failing to address destructive EU environmental infrastructure policies like turbine installations blocking migratory fish routes.  
EFD opposes fundamentally the prioritization of market integration mechanisms that ignore tangible solutions like direct fisheries-funded eel relocation programs proven effective in Dutch waters.  
The proposal contradicts EFD's principle of subsidiarity by centralizing service sector governance while neglecting member state-led conservation initiatives requiring EU barrier removal.  
EFD condemns the issue's silence on reallocating Single Market resources to physically eliminate aquatic obstacles - the root cause of species decline per EFD's analysis.  
This framework overlooks critical EFD demands for maintaining compensatory fishing industry measures until structural barriers to natural migration are permanently resolved.

ECR strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on eliminating disproportionate administrative burdens, aligning perfectly with ECR’s commitment to reducing barriers for cross-border service providers.  
ECR applauds the prioritization of mutual recognition of standards, which advances competitiveness and mirrors ECR’s advocacy for streamlined regulatory coherence.  
ECR proposes amending proportionality assessments to mandate independent scientific reviews, ensuring evidence-based governance while fully endorsing the issue’s enforcement mechanisms.  
ECR endorses the call for strict non-discrimination rules, reflecting ECR’s zero-tolerance stance against unjustified territorial or economic restrictions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about persistent barriers hindering the full potential of the EU Single Market for services, which accounts for over 65% of EU GDP and employment, with services covered by the Services Directive contributing 45% of GDP. Despite progress since the 2006 Directive, fragmented implementation, disproportionate administrative burdens, and unjustified restrictions—such as territorial limits, economic needs tests, and discriminatory practices—continue to impede cross-border services, costing up to 2.6% of potential GDP growth over 5-10 years. The resolution emphasized prioritizing high-growth sectors like business services, construction, tourism, and retail, and urged Member States to eliminate barriers, enforce proportionality assessments, and enhance mutual recognition of standards. It highlighted the need for better governance, including upgraded Points of Single Contact (PSCs), streamlined SOLVIT procedures, and stronger use of the IMI system to resolve cross-border disputes. The Parliament called for strict enforcement of non-discrimination rules, zero tolerance for unjustified restrictions, and faster infringement procedures (within 18 months) to address non-compliance. It stressed the importance of balancing market integration with social protections, worker rights, and job quality, while excluding sectors like healthcare and social services from the Directive’s scope. The resolution also advocated for digital services expansion, pension portability reforms, and targeted Commission guidance to clarify proportionality and public interest justifications, aiming to unlock growth, competitiveness, and job creation while safeguarding the EU’s social market economy.

title: Internal market scoreboard: REPORT on the Internal Market Scoreboard
background: Persistent transposition delays and compliance deficits in EU Member States, alongside fragmented application of single market rules, prompted regular monitoring through Commission scoreboards and tools like SOLVIT. The Parliament will discuss improving governance mechanisms to address gaps in timely implementation of internal market legislation and enhance cross-border problem resolution for citizens and businesses.

stances.stance:
EFD partially upholds the issue’s focus on transposition mechanisms but entirely disputes with its inadequate attention to product safety oversight, a core EFD consumer protection priority.  
EFD requests revisions to strengthen certification body mandates, citing recurring market scandals like contaminated French poultry and repackaged road salt as evidence of systemic gaps.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as harmonized food quality controls, which Paška’s examples show enable hazardous products to undermine single market integrity.  
EFD demands amendments to Section 4 on redress mechanisms to include stricter penalties for negligent certification authorities and real-time product recall protocols.  
This aligns partially with EFD’s emphasis on national sovereignty in market regulation but fails to address fragmented enforcement enabling low-quality goods, contrary to their consumer-first principles.

ALDE totally agrees the issue’s emphasis on strict enforcement of timely directive transposition, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eliminating internal market fragmentation and ensuring equal competitive conditions.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with leveraging Article 260(3) of the Lisbon Treaty to impose fines for non-compliance, reflecting their unwavering stance on binding accountability mechanisms to uphold EU law integrity.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s recognition of Malta’s exemplary transposition record and Estonia’s compliance, reinforcing ALDE’s prioritization of benchmarking excellence to drive peer accountability among Member States.  
ALDE totally agrees enhancing SOLVIT’s visibility and resources, viewing it as essential to fulfilling their manifesto goal of streamlining cross-border dispute issue and empowering citizens within the single market.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for regular Single Market Forums, mirroring their advocacy for structured dialogue to dismantle regulatory obstacles and sustain the internal market’s role as Europe’s growth engine.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent delays and deficiencies in Member States’ transposition and implementation of EU internal market legislation, noting the average transposition deficit of 1.2% exceeded the 1% target, with 85 directives remaining untransposed in at least one Member State and two directives over two years overdue. It highlighted Malta’s exemplary transposition record, Belgium’s poor performance, and Estonia’s strong compliance across indicators. The resolution stressed the critical role of the Internal Market Scoreboard in monitoring compliance and welcomed the Commission’s Annual Governance Check-up for consolidating tools like SOLVIT, which resolves misapplication cases within 10 weeks on average, though urged enhanced resources, training, and visibility for SOLVIT to address fragmentation and underuse. Parliament called for stricter enforcement of infringement procedures, particularly in taxation and environment sectors (constituting nearly 50% of cases), and urged Member States to improve transposition quality through correlation tables and reduce delays. It emphasized the need for better coordination between EU assistance services (e.g., Your Europe, Points of Single Contact) to streamline citizen and business access to rights, advocated for regular Single Market Forums to address obstacles, and pushed for improved public awareness of single market benefits. The resolution also urged leveraging the Lisbon Treaty’s Article 260(3) to impose fines for non-compliance and demanded Commission evaluations of disability-related market barriers and petitions’ impact on legislation. Overall, it framed timely, accurate transposition and effective redress mechanisms as vital to unlocking growth and competitiveness amid economic challenges.

title: Governance of the single market: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on the governance of the Single Market
background: Persistent transposition deficits and incomplete implementation of Single Market rules by EU member states, alongside rising regulatory fragmentation, hindered economic integration and growth, undermining the Europe 2020 Strategy’s objectives. The Parliament will discuss strengthening governance mechanisms to enhance the Single Market’s effectiveness in fostering competitiveness, job creation, and social cohesion.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on completing the Single Market through harmonized legislation and reduced administrative burdens for SMEs, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to competitive entrepreneurship.  
ALDE approves the call for smarter IT tools and digital market integration as critical enhancements to cross-border business operations and citizen empowerment.  
ALDE proposes strengthening communication strategies to better demonstrate the Single Market's value to SMEs, noting current awareness gaps despite existing EU outreach efforts.  
ALDE applauds the linkage between governance reforms and fiscal discipline, echoing their insistence on structural reforms in labor markets and pension systems for sustainable recovery.  
ALDE emphasizes strict enforcement of transposition deadlines to rebuild EU credibility, aligning with their issue-backed demand for Article 26(3) TFEU governance frameworks.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue’s alignment with austerity-driven governance frameworks like the European Semester, which prioritize fiscal consolidation over public investment and social protection.  
GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the emphasis on labor market flexibility and temporary contracts, which institutionalize precarious work and erode pension sustainability.  
GUE/NGL condemns the failure to address how austerity measures—embedded in Single Market fiscal convergence—directly fuel unemployment and poverty, contradicting stated social cohesion goals.  
GUE/NGL challenges the issue’s reliance on private sector-led growth, noting corporate profit hoarding and disinvestment as root causes of economic stagnation.  
GUE/NGL demands rejection of debt repayment frameworks that transfer banking crisis costs to workers, advocating instead for radical public investment in jobs and services.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to complete and strengthen the Single Market to boost growth, competitiveness, and job creation, emphasizing its role as the backbone of the EU’s economic recovery and the Europe 2020 Strategy. Despite 20 years of existence, the Single Market remains incomplete due to Member States’ failure to fully transpose approximately 1,500 directives and 1,000 regulations, with transposition deficits rising from 0.7% in 2009 to 1.2% in 2012 before improving to 0.9%, undermining trust in the EU. The resolution called for enhanced governance, including a legislative framework under Article 26(3) TFEU, to improve transposition, implementation, and enforcement of rules, balancing economic, social, and environmental priorities while integrating consumer protection, social rights, and sustainability. It stressed the importance of reducing regulatory burdens for SMEs and micro-enterprises through tailored legislation, while safeguarding health and safety standards, and advocated for one-stop shops, digital market completion, and accessible services for persons with disabilities. The Parliament highlighted fragmented services markets, low labor mobility, and administrative barriers, urging simplified recognition of professional qualifications and smarter IT tools to empower citizens and businesses. Social cohesion, fiscal convergence, and prevention of social dumping were emphasized, alongside calls for consistent enforcement of EU directives, strengthened cross-border cooperation, and alignment of national action plans with EU guidelines to foster growth, employment, and a level playing field. The resolution also linked Single Market governance to the European Semester, advocating for a coherent framework to address market deficiencies, support regional growth, and integrate accessibility under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

title: High common level of network and information security: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning measures to ensure a high common level of network and information security across the Union
background: Growing cyberattack incidents targeting critical infrastructure sectors and heightened vulnerabilities in EU digital systems, compounded by disparate national capabilities and coordination gaps, prompted legislative action. The Parliament will discuss establishing Union-wide standards for network and information security to protect essential services and cross-border data flows.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the revised directive's focus on critical infrastructure protection and flexibility, aligning with their longstanding commitment to adaptable cybersecurity measures in rapidly evolving digital landscapes.  
GREEN_EFA approves the use of Article 114 as the legal basis, ensuring a civilian-oriented framework that safeguards the internal market while addressing emerging threats, consistent with their advocacy for consumer rights and digital sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the importance of addressing military-derived cybersecurity risks revealed by Snowden disclosures, proposing enhanced safeguards against state-actor threats while maintaining the directive’s civilian governance structure.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on cross-border collaboration and resilience-building measures, which effectively advance their priority of EU-wide coordinated action to counter cyberattacks.  
GREEN_EFA stresses the need for ongoing parliamentary oversight to ensure transparency, urging proactive updates to the framework as technological challenges evolve.

ECR strongly approves the directive's focus on critical infrastructure sectors like finance and healthcare, aligning with their priority to safeguard digital single market stability through risk assessments.  
ECR approves the emphasis on member state sovereignty in cybersecurity implementation, ensuring national agencies retain primary responsibility for threat response frameworks.  
ECR highlights enhancement opportunities in mandatory breach reporting, proposing trust-based cooperation mechanisms over rigid compliance to prevent superficial "tick-box" approaches.  
ECR commends the cross-border threat detection mechanisms as vital for early cyberattack prevention, reinforcing ECR's commitment to interoperable EU security architectures.  
ECR endorses the proportionality principle for private sector obligations, noting businesses' inherent incentives to protect infrastructure without excessive regulatory burdens.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns based on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0048) to enhance cybersecurity measures under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aiming to harmonize laws for a safer digital internal market. It reaffirmed its commitment to the 2013 Cybersecurity Strategy, emphasizing the need for an open, secure cyberspace through coordinated EU-wide action, critical infrastructure protection, and cross-border collaboration. The resolution integrated inputs from multiple committees—Internal Market, Industry, Civil Liberties, and Foreign Affairs—and aligned with the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2013 opinion, stressing consumer rights, threat prevention, and resilience against cyberattacks. It urged the Commission to maintain transparency by re-engaging Parliament if proposing significant amendments, ensuring alignment with prior legislative efforts to bolster cybersecurity frameworks and address evolving digital threats.

title: Recreational craft and personal watercraft: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on recreational craft and personal watercraft
background: The European Commission proposed updating 2003 recreational craft regulations to address market fragmentation, inconsistent national standards, and evolving environmental concerns, impacting 37,000 EU businesses. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing safety, emissions, and design requirements to strengthen the internal market while balancing industry competitiveness and environmental protection.

stances.stance:
EFD partially promotes the harmonization objectives but requests amending Article 2 to clarify classification thresholds between small inflatables and large yachts  
EFD urges revisions to Annex I environmental provisions to include mandatory lifecycle assessments for propulsion systems  
EFD highlights unresolved contradictions with Directive 2013/53/EU regarding cross-border market surveillance mechanisms  
EFD requests stricter conformity assessment protocols in Article 12 to prevent divergent national interpretations

ECR applauds the integration of stakeholder consultations, particularly the EESC’s input, as a model for balanced policymaking that respects both industry and environmental priorities.  
ECR emphasizes vigilance in aligning this directive with existing EU environmental laws to avoid regulatory overlaps, ensuring streamlined compliance for member states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0456) concerning internal market harmonization under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance following input from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, alongside opinions from the Environment and Transport committees. The resolution emphasized the need to align legislation with single market objectives while addressing cross-border consumer and environmental concerns. It endorsed the Commission’s proposal but urged vigilance against market fragmentation, calling for coherence with existing EU laws. The Parliament instructed its President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, and requested that the Commission re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments, ensuring continued legislative oversight. The resolution also acknowledged the European Economic and Social Committee’s December 2011 opinion, reinforcing stakeholder consultation in the legislative process.

title: Repeal of directives regarding metrology: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directives 71//317/EEC, 71/347/EEC, 71/349/EEC, 74/148/EEC, 75/33/EEC, 76/765/EEC, 76/766/EEC, and 86/217/EEC regarding metrology
background: Eight EU metrology directives regulating specific measuring instruments became obsolete due to international standards and technological advancements, creating redundant regulations amid broader EU efforts to reduce administrative burdens. The Parliament will discuss repealing these directives as part of regulatory simplification in metrology to eliminate redundant legislation.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the repeal of outdated metrology directives to modernize technical standards and reduce regulatory redundancies, aligning with efforts to ease burdens on businesses.  
EFD advises expediting the European Commission's proposal for a new Measuring Instruments Directive to ensure seamless regulatory transition and legal clarity.  
EFD highlights the capability of European businesses to utilize international standards and trade organizations to maintain market stability during the interim period.  
EFD emphasizes the importance of minimizing bureaucratic constraints and tax pressures on businesses to foster a dynamic and balanced European market.  
EFD acknowledges the issue's alignment with streamlining metrology frameworks but urges proactive legislative action to prevent future regulatory gaps.

ALDE absolutely endorses the repeal of outdated metrology directives as a critical step toward harmonizing technical standards and eliminating regulatory redundancies, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to streamlining EU legislation.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s emphasis on leveraging the mutual recognition principle to ensure free movement of goods, which advances ALDE's priority of fostering cross-border trade through regulatory efficiency.  
ALDE strongly agrees the integration of repealed directives’ provisions into the Measurements Instruments Directive, ensuring legal clarity and continuity while upholding consumer protection and measurement accuracy.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of preemptively addressing potential legal gaps through the Commission’s evaluation mechanism, reflecting ALDE's proactive stance on adaptive governance and technical coherence.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s alignment with modernized calibration practices as essential for maintaining global competitiveness, consistent with ALDE's advocacy for innovation-driven regulatory frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the harmonization of technical standards across several EU directives, specifically addressing metrology and measurement instruments. The resolution highlighted the need to update or repeal outdated directives, including Directive 75/33/EEC on Cold Water Meters for Non-Clean Water, Directives 76/765/EEC and 76/766/EEC governing Alcohol Meters and Alcohol Tables, Directives 71/317/EEC and 74/148/EEC on Medium and Above-Medium Accuracy Weights, Directive 86/217/EEC on Tyre Pressure Gauges for Motor Vehicles, Directive 71/347/EEC on Standard Mass of Grain, and Directive 71/349/EEC on Calibration of Ship Tanks. It emphasized modernizing these frameworks to align with current technological and regulatory requirements, ensuring consistency in measurement accuracy, consumer protection, and cross-border trade. The resolution underscored the importance of maintaining legal clarity and eliminating redundancies while preserving the directives’ core objectives related to standardization and calibration practices.

title: Report: Catherine Trautmann - Electronic communication networks and services, 3rd reading on the joint text approved by the Conciliation Committee: REPORT on the joint text approved by the Conciliation Committee for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directives 2002/21/EC on a common regulatory framework for electronic communications networks and services, 2002/19/EC on access to, and interconnection of, electronic communications networks and associated facilities, and 2002/20/EC on the authorisation of electronic communications networks and services
background: The 2002 EU regulatory framework for electronic communications became outdated due to technological advances in high-speed internet, mobile services, and spectrum management, alongside evolving market competition and consumer protection needs in a digitalizing economy. The Parliament will discuss reforms to harmonize rules on network access, market authorization, and cross-border service coordination.

stances.stance:
ECR strongly sanctions the finalized legislative package, particularly its robust consumer rights protections and net neutrality safeguards, which align with their commitment to market transparency and user empowerment.  
ECR applauds the strengthened provisions on data breach notification and cookie consent requirements as critical advancements in digital consumer protection.  
ECR welcomes the Commission’s declaration on net neutrality enforcement, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for open internet principles.  
ECR proposes enhancing clarity in implementing the data breach framework to prevent divergent interpretations by member states, while fully endorsing the agreed text.  
ECR emphasizes the urgency of swift Commission action to operationalize the directive’s consumer-centric measures across all EU markets.

GUE_NGL totally againsts the issue’s failure to mandate judicial review for user restrictions, enabling arbitrary measures by authorities and ISPs under Article 1(3a).  
GUE_NGL rejects the exclusion of binding net neutrality guarantees, which permits commercial agreements to fragment internet access into restricted channels (Amendment 138).  
GUE_NGL condemns the subordination of freedom of expression to internal market rules, as Article 2(7) grants the European Court of Justice authority over civil liberties.  
GUE_NGL opposes the prioritization of corporate interests over user rights, allowing service providers to impose restrictions via contractual terms (Annex IV).  
GUE_NGL declares the procedural framework incompatible with democratic principles, as it institutionalizes surveillance risks under Recital 22.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the joint text negotiated through the conciliation process, which reconciled differing positions on the Commission’s amended proposal (COM(2008)0724) and the Council’s common position. It formally adopted the finalized legislative act, instructing its President to sign it jointly with the Council’s President under Article 254(1) of the EC Treaty, thereby finalizing the legislative procedure. The Parliament further directed its Secretary-General to verify procedural compliance, coordinate with the Council’s Secretary-General to publish the act alongside the Commission’s explanatory statement in the Official Journal of the EU, and ensure transparency. Additionally, it mandated its President to transmit the resolution to the Council and Commission, concluding the legislative process initiated under the Commission’s original proposal (COM(2007)0697) and subsequent amendments.

title: Non-automatic weighing instruments: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States relating to making available on the market of non-automatic weighing instruments (recast)
background: Following the Lisbon Treaty’s institutional reforms and ongoing efforts to modernize EU internal market regulations, the European Commission proposed updates to harmonize technical standards for industrial products. resolution: The European Parliament raised that the resolution, based on the Consultative Working Party’s assessment, confirmed the Commission’s proposal (COM(2011)0766) as a codification of existing legislation without substantive amendments, maintaining the original provisions alongside identified changes. Additionally, it mandated the transmission of Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural adherence under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the Interinstitutional Agreement of 28 November 2001 on recasting legal acts.

title: Online consumer dispute resolution: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes (Regulation on consumer ODR)
background: Growing cross-border e-commerce in the EU faced challenges with consumer trust due to inconsistent national alternative dispute resolution mechanisms and obstacles in resolving transnational disputes efficiently. The Parliament will discuss establishing an EU-wide online dispute resolution framework to standardize consumer protection and facilitate accessible redress mechanisms for digital transactions.

EPP highlights the issue's 90-day dispute issue timeframe as a transformative advancement that effectively advances EPP's priority of judicial efficiency and consumer trust in cross-border commerce.  
EPP applauds the mandatory multilingual accessibility of the ODR interface, recognizing this as critical for ensuring equal consumer rights across all member states in line with single market principles.  
EPP emphasizes the issue's compatibility with successful national ADR models like Baden-Württemberg's online mediation system, demonstrating its practical alignment with proven market-enhancing tools.  
EPP commends the inclusion of post-service employment safeguards for ADR personnel as essential for maintaining expert dispute issue quality while upholding ethical standards.

GREEN_EFA applauds the multilingual interactive web portal as a critical step toward equitable access to justice, aligning perfectly with their commitment to linguistic inclusivity and digital empowerment.

GREEN_EFA endorses the single-entry point design for out-of-court settlements, recognizing its potential to reduce bureaucratic fragmentation and empower vulnerable consumers.  
GREEN_EFA affirms that the issue’s focus on cost-effective dispute issue directly mirrors their manifesto goals of economic fairness and procedural transparency in cross-border transactions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0794) concerning internal market and consumer protection measures, endorsing the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s report and the Committee on Legal Affairs’ opinion. It formally adopted its stance, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending to introduce substantial amendments or replace it, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and alignment with EU legislative frameworks.

title: Package travel and assisted travel arrangements: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and assisted travel arrangements, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004, Directive 2011/83/EU and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC
background: The 1990 EU Package Travel Directive, predating widespread internet use, lacked provisions for online bookings and dynamic travel packages, creating consumer protection gaps. The European Commission proposed modernizing rules in 2013 to address digital market developments. The Parliament will discuss updating consumer safeguards for package travel and assisted arrangements in the digital era.

stances.stance:

Postal services were urged to enhance delivery reliability, interoperability, and cost efficiency, while public transport policies should prioritize accessibility for the elderly and people with limited mobility, aligning with climate goals. resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the underutilization and limited awareness of SOLVIT, a cross-border dispute resolution mechanism handling approximately 1,300 cases annually with a 90% resolution rate within 70 days, while stressing the need to enhance its effectiveness, visibility, and accessibility. It emphasized SOLVIT’s role in addressing misapplication of EU law, particularly in labor rights, social security, pensions, and equal treatment, and urged Member States to allocate adequate resources, improve staff training, and expand SOLVIT’s capacity to handle complex business cases, noting that 91.6% of citizens remain unaware of single-market problem-solving tools. The resolution called for better integration of SOLVIT with platforms like Your Europe, which saw 11,000 daily visitors in 2012, and advocated for linking national portals to improve accessibility for vulnerable groups, including people with disabilities. It highlighted the need to address structural non-compliance by Member States through stricter enforcement, peer reviews, and faster infringement procedures, while promoting SOLVIT as an alternative to litigation. The Parliament welcomed SOLVIT’s updated mandate under Commission Recommendation 2013/461/EU to tackle systemic breaches of EU law and urged measurable targets for performance, including regional SOLVIT centers (SOLVITRegio) to increase proximity to citizens. It also stressed data protection standards, improved coordination with EU Pilot, and EU-wide awareness campaigns to boost SOLVIT’s visibility by 2020, alongside integrating it into the European Semester for economic governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about persistent late payments in commercial transactions, particularly harming SMEs, which face liquidity issues, increased bankruptcy risks (1 in 4 EU bankruptcies linked to late payments), and unfair power imbalances with larger firms. It emphasized Directive 2011/7/EU’s role in setting payment terms (30 days for public authorities, 60 days for businesses), statutory interest (≥8% above ECB rates), and minimum €40 compensation for recovery costs, but noted inadequate enforcement, with 60% of businesses still paid late in B2B transactions and 95% of SMEs experiencing delayed payments. The resolution urged stricter national enforcement, including shorter payment terms (ideally 30 days), mandatory transparency on payment behavior, and administrative sanctions for non-compliance. It highlighted the economic cost of late payments, estimating €158 million daily savings and 6.5 million additional jobs if delays were reduced. Recommendations included promoting mediation services, SME training in credit management, leveraging digital payment technologies, and aligning public procurement rules with prompt payment principles. The Parliament also called for EU-wide guidelines to clarify ambiguous terms in the Directive, stronger synergies between late payment rules and sector-specific initiatives (e.g., food supply chains), and Commission action against non-compliant Member States, including ongoing infringement procedures against Greece, Slovakia, Spain, and Italy.

title: CE marked fertilising products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down rules on the making available on the market of CE marked fertilising products and amending Regulations (EC) No 1069/2009 and (EC) No 1107/2009
background: The EU's 2003 fertiliser regulations limited CE marking to inorganic products, creating market fragmentation. Circular Economy Action Plan priorities emphasized waste-derived fertilisers. EU reliance on imported phosphate, often cadmium-contaminated and sourced from geopolitically sensitive regions like Morocco-occupied Western Sahara, raised sustainability and health concerns. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing CE-marked fertiliser standards to expand market access for organic/recycled products, reduce contaminants, and address strategic resource dependencies.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the proposed cadmium limits as unsupported by conclusive scientific evidence on soil-to-food contamination pathways  
EPP opposes fundamentally the 60mg/kg cadmium threshold for jeopardizing EU fertilizer industry competitiveness and phosphate supply security  
This issue conflicts with EPP's principle of evidence-based policymaking by setting arbitrary contaminant reduction timelines  
The proposal overlooks critical geopolitical risks by forcing increased dependence on Russian mineral phosphate imports  
EPP condemns the lack of transitional periods for industry adaptation as contradictory to responsible regulatory change management

SD strongly endorses the harmonization of CE marked fertilisers as a critical step toward circular agriculture, aligning with their commitment to sustainable resource reuse and reduced environmental impact.  
SD applauds the balanced approach to cadmium reduction timelines, ensuring both health protections through gradual contaminant limits and industrial adaptability, mirroring their 2023 agro-environmental policy priorities.  
SD proposes strengthening Article 4 to explicitly safeguard the Nitrates Directive’s integrity, ensuring fertilisation limits remain binding to prevent intensive farming practices and soil degradation.  
SD endorses mandatory CE labeling for organic fertilisers as a transparency milestone, advancing consumer safety and fair market access for innovative circular economy products.  
SD highlights the need for accelerated research funding (Amendment 12bis) to achieve sub-20mg/kg cadmium thresholds ahead of the 12-year deadline, transforming this into a competitive advantage for EU agriculture.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning internal market and consumer protection matters, adopting its first-reading stance based on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s report (A8-0270/2017) and incorporating opinions from the Committees on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety; Agriculture and Rural Development; and International Trade. The resolution emphasized adherence to the Commission’s original proposal (COM(2016)0157) under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which aims to harmonize laws affecting the internal market. It called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and parliamentary oversight. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring procedural compliance and inter-institutional coordination.

title: Cableway installations: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cableway installations
background: The EU's 2000 Cableways Directive faced divergent national transpositions, creating internal market barriers and regulatory inconsistencies. The Parliament will discuss a proposed regulation to modernize safety standards and harmonize technical requirements for cableway installations across member states.

stances.stance:
EFDD slightly approves the harmonization framework but requests revisions to exempt member states with existing high safety standards from redundant cableway regulations.  
EFDD opposes the issue's blanket application of Article 114 TFEU, arguing it absolutely rejects with the principle that transport safety governance should prioritize national expertise over centralized EU mandates.  
The proposal's mandatory harmonization overlooks critical aspects of subsidiarity by failing to prove localized cableway oversight insufficient for consumer protection.  
EFDD challenges the necessity of expanding EU regulatory scope, citing unresolved concerns about bureaucratic duplication in maintenance protocols for alpine infrastructure.  
This approach remains inconsistent with EFDD's stance that mutual recognition of standards—not harmonization—ensures efficient cross-border trade in tourism sectors.

SD totally endorses the issue’s harmonization of safety protocols for cableway installations, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to worker and consumer protection across critical infrastructure.  
SD applauds the exclusion of non-essential bureaucratic requirements, such as overly broad equipment categorization, which preserves regulatory efficiency while ensuring rigorous safety enforcement.  
The issue effectively advances SD’s priority of legal certainty for manufacturers, particularly in streamlining certification processes for safety-critical cableway components.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s balanced approach to personal protective equipment standards, ensuring fire-resistant gear and industrial helmets meet EU-wide safety benchmarks without stifling innovation.  
This aligns perfectly with SD’s longstanding advocacy for harmonized market rules that protect both professionals operating cableways and end-users relying on their safety.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2014 proposal (COM(2014)0187) concerning internal market and consumer protection measures, as detailed in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s report (A8-0063/2015). It formally adopted its stance, urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending substantial amendments or a replacement text, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU legislative procedures under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

title: Dual quality of products in the Single Market: REPORT on dual quality of products in the single market
background: Reports of differing product compositions under identical branding in Central and Eastern European markets, alongside the European Commission’s 2017 guidance on consumer protection law application, prompted scrutiny of single market equity. The Parliament will discuss dual-quality products’ implications for consumer trust and fair competition within the EU internal market.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue's mandate for harmonized testing methodologies and cross-border enforcement, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to equal market rules across all Member States.  
EPP approves the explicit prohibition of dual-quality marketing under UCPD revisions while proposing minor clarifications to distinguish legitimate regional recipe adaptations from deceptive practices.  
EPP strongly endorses creating a public product database and EU monitoring body, effectively advancing EPP's priority of consumer transparency without establishing redundant institutions.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity for distinct packaging when product compositions differ significantly, urging amendment of Annex I to Directive 2005/29/EC to specify visual differentiation requirements.  
EPP applauds the focus on SME protections and competition law enforcement as fully consistent with EPP's 2024 Single Market Strategy against exploitative corporate practices.

ENF fundamentally rejects the issue's centralized testing methodology as incompatible with their principle of national sovereignty over consumer standards.  
ENF opposes the creation of an EU monitoring body, asserting it infringes on member states' rights to set production norms reflecting local purchasing power and tastes.  
The proposal's harmonization requirements contradict ENF's defense of producer freedom to adapt recipes to regional preferences without bureaucratic interference.  
ENF condemns the public database of test results as a tool for EU overreach that undermines competitive market mechanisms between states.  
The issue's reliance on amended UCPD enforcement conflicts with ENF's stance against Brussels-based regulation of commercial practices best managed nationally.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the widespread issue of dual-quality products in the EU single market, where identically branded and packaged goods—particularly food, detergents, cosmetics, and baby products—are sold with significant differences in composition, ingredients, or quality across Member States, disproportionately affecting Central and Eastern European countries. Citing evidence from national surveys and laboratory tests, the resolution emphasized that such practices mislead consumers, undermine trust in the single market, and constitute unfair commercial practices under Directive 2005/29/EC (UCPD). It welcomed the Commission’s allocation of €2 million to the Joint Research Centre (JRC) to develop a harmonized testing methodology by end-2018, alongside initiatives like the New Deal for Consumers, which proposes amending the UCPD to explicitly prohibit marketing products as identical when their composition differs significantly. The resolution called for stricter enforcement, cross-border cooperation among national authorities, penalties for non-compliance, and transparency measures such as a public database of test results. It urged manufacturers to avoid misleading packaging, clearly inform consumers of regional recipe variations, and consider EU-wide quality logos, while stressing that product differentiation must not lower quality or exploit purchasing power disparities. The Parliament also advocated for a specialized EU monitoring body to oversee compliance and highlighted the need to protect SMEs, local producers, and consumer rights through enhanced support for consumer organizations and stricter application of competition law.

title: EU eGovernment action plan 2016-2020: REPORT on the EU eGovernment Action Plan 2016-2020
background: The EU's prior eGovernment initiatives aimed to modernize public administration through digital solutions, facing challenges like uneven digital infrastructure, cross-border interoperability gaps, and cybersecurity risks. The Parliament will discuss the 2016-2020 Action Plan's role in advancing public sector digital transformation and addressing these barriers.

stances.stance:
ALDE completely sanctions the issue’s prioritization of pan-European eGovernment integration, perfectly aligning with their commitment to reducing administrative burdens and fostering seamless cross-border digital services for citizens and SMEs.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the urgency to universalize high-speed broadband access, particularly in rural regions, as a critical step toward equitable digital inclusion and economic cohesion.  
ALDE completely sanctions the emphasis on GDPR-aligned cybersecurity and data protection frameworks, which directly advance their manifesto goals of building citizen trust in digital public services.  
ALDE perfectly supports the issue’s call for interoperable systems like eIDAS and ISA2, recognizing these as foundational to achieving frictionless cross-border administrative and judicial cooperation.  
ALDE fully aligns with the imperative to maintain offline service access while scaling digital solutions, ensuring no citizen is excluded from essential public services during the transition.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's digital-by-default approach as totally disputeing with their commitment to universal public service access, noting it risks excluding 22% of Europeans who rely on offline interactions.  
GUE_NGL opposes the reliance on multinational software corporations for eGovernment infrastructure, condemning it as a surrender of technological sovereignty that leaves data vulnerable to foreign commercial exploitation.  
GUE_NGL disputes the prioritization of cost-saving measures like the "once-only" principle, arguing it subordinates equitable service delivery to austerity logic while ignoring rural broadband deficits (28% coverage in 2015).  
GUE_NGL demands binding safeguards against physical service closures, declaring the issue's passive "preference" for offline access insufficient to prevent exclusion of digitally marginalized groups.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to mandate public-sector control over digital tools and data storage, warning that GDPR compliance alone cannot prevent corporate capture of citizen information through privatized platforms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of advancing eGovernment as a cornerstone of the Digital Single Market, emphasizing the need for inclusive, secure, and interoperable digital public services by 2022 to reduce administrative burdens and costs, particularly for SMEs. Key priorities included implementing the "once-only" principle, projected to save €5 billion annually by 2017, and establishing a single digital gateway for cross-border services. The resolution highlighted the necessity of open data, robust cybersecurity aligned with GDPR, and enhanced digital infrastructure, noting that only 28% of rural households had fixed broadband in 2015 and urging expanded high-speed connectivity, including 5G, via the Connecting Europe Facility. It stressed interoperability through initiatives like the ISA2 programme and eIDAS Regulation for secure digital identities, while advocating mobile-friendly services (only one-third of public websites met this standard) and multilingual access in border regions. Addressing digital divides, the resolution called for training programs to improve skills, inclusive design for disabled users, and maintaining offline service access to prevent exclusion (22% of Europeans still prefer non-digital interactions). Cross-border judicial tools like e-Justice Portal, e-CODEX, and the European Case Law Identifier (ECLI) were endorsed, alongside eProcurement adoption to boost transparency. The European Cloud Initiative and Wifi4EU were supported to enhance data-driven public services, while urging Member States to accelerate reforms in business registers, eHealth, and social security data exchange (EESSI). Overall, the resolution emphasized balancing innovation with trust, security, and equity in digital transformation.

title: Appliances burning gaseous fuels: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on appliances burning gaseous fuels
background: The European Commission proposed updating EU legislation on gas appliances to enhance safety standards and market harmonization, addressing evolving technologies and risks like carbon monoxide emissions. Existing directives from 1989 and 2000 required modernization to align with current technical requirements and single market principles. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to ensure uniform safety protocols for gas-fueled appliances across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely accepts the harmonized safety standards for gas appliances, perfectly aligning with their commitment to consumer protection and energy efficiency as highlighted in the issue's focus on reducing carbon monoxide risks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's modernization of personal protective equipment regulations, emphasizing the elimination of bureaucratic barriers while maintaining high consumer safety benchmarks.  
EPP fully supports the transition from directives to regulations for cableway installations, ensuring uniform application across Member States and enhancing the single market's competitiveness.  
EPP endorses the issue's approach to harmonizing technical specifications, which effectively advances their priority of creating a seamless internal market for industrial goods.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the emphasis on market surveillance mechanisms, recognizing their critical role in preventing fraudulent products and safeguarding European consumers.

EFDD slightly sanctions the harmonization framework under Article 114 but requests revision of Clause 4 to exempt member states from mandatory alignment where national safety standards exceed EU baselines  
EFDD fully condemns the issue's presumption of harmonization necessity, citing Margot Parker's critique that it imposes one-size-fits-all solutions inconsistent with subsidiarity principles  
EFDD demands amendment to Recital 12 to require independent cost-benefit analysis of market harmonization, addressing concerns about regulatory overreach raised in the PPE Regulation precedent  
This proposal conflicts with EFDD's stance that binding EU-wide technical specifications undermine national sovereignty, as evidenced by forced UK compliance despite objections  
EFDD requires insertion of Article 7a permitting member states to maintain existing certification regimes until 2030, aligning with their manifesto commitment to gradual regulatory convergence

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2014)0258) concerning the internal market and consumer protection, as outlined in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s report (A8-0147/2015), and adopted its first-reading stance under Article 114 and Article 294 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which govern the harmonization of internal market laws and the ordinary legislative procedure. The resolution emphasized the Parliament’s formal adoption of its negotiated position, urged the European Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts to the original proposal, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and transparency. The focus remained on safeguarding legislative coherence and parliamentary oversight in shaping EU internal market policies.

title: Approval and market surveillance of motor vehicles and their trailers, and of systems, components and separate technical units intended for such vehicles: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approval and market surveillance of motor vehicles and their trailers, and of systems, components and separate technical units intended for such vehicles
background: The 2015 Volkswagen emissions scandal exposed systemic weaknesses in EU vehicle type-approval processes, revealing inconsistent enforcement, inadequate testing protocols, and conflicts of interest between national authorities and manufacturers under existing mutual recognition frameworks. The Parliament will discuss reforms to harmonize vehicle approval standards and strengthen market surveillance mechanisms across member states.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the creation of an EU-wide vehicle surveillance agency as bureaucratic overreach that centralizes power in the Commission while ignoring its past regulatory failures  
ENF opposes the issue’s disproportionate targeting of German automotive excellence, framing legitimate industrial success as environmental criminality  
ENF condemns the proposal’s failure to address root causes like unrealistic lab-test standards that enabled emission discrepancies, not lack of oversight  
ENF fully disapproves with attempts to weaken European automakers’ global competitiveness through punitive fees and administrative burdens favoring non-EU rivals  
ENF rejects the issue’s disregard for French industrial interests, particularly Renault’s compliance under existing rules and damage from euro exchange rates

SD firmly approves the creation of a centralized EU vehicle surveillance agency, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to eliminating national conflicts of interest and ensuring industry-independent oversight.  
SD firmly approves mandatory consumer compensation mechanisms for emissions fraud cases, mirroring US precedents to strengthen deterrence against corporate malpractice.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's prohibition of defeat device software, reinforcing SD's environmental protection priorities through lifetime vehicle compliance monitoring.  
SD firmly approves enhanced Commission intervention powers to address regulatory gaps, effectively advancing cross-border enforcement harmonization as outlined in the Dalton report.  
SD perfectly supports harmonized technical standards and market surveillance protocols, closing legal loopholes that permitted past diesel emission scandals through unified EU testing methodologies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2016 proposal (COM(2016)0031) to harmonize rules under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aimed at ensuring the functioning of the internal market. The resolution, informed by committees on Internal Market and Consumer Protection, Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and Transport and Tourism, as well as the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2016 opinion, emphasized adopting measures to align national regulations, address disparities, and enhance cross-border consistency. It underscored the need for coherent EU-wide standards while safeguarding consumer rights, environmental protections, and transport safety. The Parliament urged the Commission to avoid substantial amendments without renewed parliamentary scrutiny and to ensure future proposals align with the resolution’s objectives, reflecting a balanced approach to market integration and regulatory harmonization.

title: A longer lifetime for products: benefits for consumers and companies: REPORT on a longer lifetime for products: benefits for consumers and companies
background: Growing concerns over resource depletion, environmental sustainability, and consumer demand for durable goods, alongside EU circular economy initiatives and national measures addressing planned obsolescence, have highlighted product lifespan challenges. The Parliament will discuss strategies to extend product lifetimes for economic, environmental, and consumer benefits within the EU single market framework.

stances.stance:
EFDD supports the issue’s sanctions against planned obsolescence but advises amending penalty clauses to mandate proportional fines tied to corporate revenue, ensuring deterrence for large manufacturers.  
EFDD endorses accessible spare parts provisions but proposes extending minimum availability timelines from 7 to 10 years for electronics to align with consumer expectations of product longevity.  
EFDD advises upgrading the voluntary durability label to a mandatory certification scheme, enforceable through standardized lifecycle testing protocols to prevent regional discrepancies.  
EFDD highlights the need to expand SME support beyond VAT reductions, urging dedicated EU funding for repair-sector startups and vocational training programs to reverse job loss trends.  
EFDD cautions that voluntary repair manuals risk inconsistent implementation, recommending binding requirements for digital repair platforms accessible across all member states.

GUE_NGL totally agrees the issue’s binding measures to eradicate planned obsolescence, perfectly aligning with their anti-capitalist critique of production-driven waste.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the emphasis on relocalizing repair-sector jobs, viewing this as essential to countering resource extraction imbalances in the Global South.  
GUE_NGL fully supports mandating public procurement of durable goods, recognizing this as a foundational step toward degrowth-oriented systemic transformation.  
GUE_NGL applauds the criminalization of planned obsolescence and extended producer liability, seeing these as vital challenges to profit-driven product lifespans.  
GUE_NGL endorses harmonized EU-wide durability standards, affirming their role in reducing energy consumption and advancing climate justice imperatives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about unsustainable consumption patterns and called for comprehensive measures to enhance product durability, repairability, and recyclability as part of transitioning to a circular economy. It urged the Commission to establish minimum resistance criteria for products, focusing on robustness, repairability, and upgradeability, and to combat planned obsolescence through an EU-wide definition, independent testing systems, and penalties for manufacturers. The resolution emphasized improving consumer information via a voluntary EU label indicating product durability, repairability, and lifespan, supported by standardized manuals and digital tools, while noting that 77% of EU consumers prefer repairing goods over replacements. It advocated for accessible spare parts, affordable repair services, and support for SMEs in the repair sector, highlighting job losses in the Netherlands (2,000 jobs lost in 7 years) and Germany (13% repair shop closures annually). The Parliament encouraged modular design, extended producer responsibility, and public procurement favoring durable goods, alongside fiscal incentives like Sweden’s VAT reduction (25% to 12%) on repairs and tax deductions for repair costs. Measures against software obsolescence included mandatory security updates, reversible upgrades, and compatibility requirements. The resolution also stressed harmonizing national initiatives, such as France’s criminalization of planned obsolescence and Austria’s repair-friendly appliance label, to strengthen the internal market, reduce electronic waste, and align with the Ecodesign Working Plan 2016-2019 and Circular Economy Package objectives.

title: Establishing the 'Customs' programme for cooperation in the field of customs: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the ‘Customs’ programme for cooperation in the field of customs
background: The EU Customs Union, central to single market integrity and external border security, confronted rising trade volumes, technological adaptation needs, and transnational security risks. The Commission proposed replacing the expiring Customs 2020 programme with enhanced cooperation tools and equipment funding. The Parliament will discuss establishing a renewed customs cooperation framework and financing modernized control infrastructure across member states.

stances.stance:
ENF strongly promotes the issue’s alignment with Treaty provisions on market harmonization and customs efficiency, advancing ENF’s priority to safeguard the EU’s financial interests through robust external border controls.  
ENF proposes enhancing internal market fairness by mandating stricter anti-distortion mechanisms to address preexisting economic disparities, ensuring the customs union’s integrity matches its external protections.  
ENF approves the emphasis on procedural transparency and legislative oversight, which aligns with their commitment to institutional accountability in trade policy governance.  
ENF underscores the necessity of pragmatic economic strategies to counterbalance globalization’s pressures, urging accelerated reforms to strengthen the EU’s competitive autonomy.

SD strongly advocates the allocation of funding for customs control equipment modernization, aligning with SD’s commitment to combating illicit trade and protecting public revenues through enhanced detection capabilities.  
SD approves the issue’s emphasis on standardizing EU-wide customs controls, which advances SD’s priority of closing operational loopholes and ensuring equitable enforcement across member states.  
SD endorses the integration of binding cybersecurity standards for customs infrastructure, effectively advancing data protection goals and mitigating risks of external interference.  
SD proposes clarifying Article 4 to explicitly restrict dual-use scenarios for purchased equipment, ensuring alignment with the instrument’s core objectives.  
SD urges accelerated Council alignment with Parliament’s standardization framework to eliminate fragmentation in customs enforcement practices.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0442) to align EU legislation with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, specifically Articles 33, 114, and 207, which govern internal market harmonization, customs procedures, and trade policy. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, emphasizing the need to ensure legal clarity and coherence in EU rules affecting goods circulation, consumer protection, and international trade. It mandated the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its initial text, safeguarding legislative oversight. Parliament also directed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and interinstitutional accountability. The resolution focused on maintaining alignment with Treaty provisions while streamlining regulatory frameworks to enhance market efficiency and legal certainty.

title: Digital single market: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on supporting consumer rights in the digital single market
background: The EU's digital single market faced fragmentation, uneven broadband access, consumer rights disparities, and concerns over data privacy and market dominance, amid its potential to generate €260 billion annually. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen consumer protections and ensure fair competition within the evolving digital economy framework.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on eliminating EU roaming charges and advancing telecom market unification as critical steps toward realizing the Digital Single Market's €260 billion potential.  
EPP fundamentally upholds the call for robust competition rules and data protection standards, aligning with their commitment to a secure yet innovation-friendly business environment.  
EPP applauds the focus on copyright modernization to protect cultural diversity while balancing creator rights with digital accessibility, mirroring their 2024 Digital Economy Manifesto priorities.  
EPP proposes refining search engine transparency requirements to ensure market-driven innovation, suggesting amendments to avoid overly prescriptive targeting of specific platforms.  
EPP emphasizes urgency in implementing the Connected Continent regulation and cross-border e-government services, highlighting their alignment with Juncker Plan investment goals for SME digitalization.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's promotion of a European ancillary copyright law, which would impose licensing fees for text excerpts and disproportionately benefit large publishers over small competitors and free knowledge exchange.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's failure to prioritize democratic principles like freedom of expression, noting the absence of safeguards for net neutrality and search engine practices as tools for democratic discourse rather than purely economic concerns.  
GREEN_EFA firmly disapproves with the issue's neglect of systemic tax justice measures, arguing that targeting individual corporations like Google distracts from addressing widespread corporate tax avoidance through frameworks like LuxLeaks.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's copyright reform approach as regressive, citing Germany and Spain's failed national experiments with ancillary copyright that restricted fair use and public access to information.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's omission of internet democratization as a core policy goal, contradicting their principle that digital infrastructure must empower civic participation before market expansion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of advancing the digital single market to unlock annual economic gains of €260 billion, enhance competitiveness, and foster sustainable growth through improved e-commerce, cross-border services, and consumer choice. It emphasized the need for universal high-speed broadband access to bridge the digital divide, ensuring inclusivity for all citizens regardless of socioeconomic status or geography, and stressed data protection, privacy, and cybersecurity as prerequisites for trust. The resolution called for swift adoption of the Data Protection Package to balance user rights with a stable business environment, urged enforcement of competition rules to prevent market monopolies and abuse, and demanded an end to EU roaming charges alongside net neutrality safeguards. It highlighted the necessity of unbiased, transparent search engine practices to ensure fair competition and consumer choice, advocated for copyright reforms to align with digital realities, and promoted cloud computing as a tool for SME growth while addressing risks like data concentration and security. Additional priorities included modernizing payment systems, implementing the Consumer Rights Directive, and advancing international standards for secure, interoperable digital services. The Parliament also underscored the role of the Connected Continent regulation in creating a unified telecoms market and stressed the need for coordinated efforts against cybercrime.

title: Establishing, as part of the Integrated Border Management Fund, the instrument for financial support for customs control equipment: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing, as part of the Integrated Border Management Fund, the instrument for financial support for customs control equipment
background: The European Union's Customs Union, integral to the single market and external trade, faced challenges from uneven customs control equipment standards across member states, impacting border security and trade efficiency. The Parliament will discuss establishing a financial instrument under the Integrated Border Management Fund to address equipment disparities and enhance customs control capabilities.

ENF advises amending Article 4 to include measures addressing internal economic disparities that undermine the customs union’s effectiveness.  
ENF suggests strengthening Section 7’s reporting requirements to mandate biannual audits evaluating progress against historical enforcement shortcomings.  
ENF expresses concern that ongoing free-trade agreements contradict the issue’s protective aims, urging parallel policy reassessment to ensure coherence.  
ENF emphasizes the need for binding accountability mechanisms in Article 9 to address member states’ inconsistent implementation of customs protocols.

ALDE fully advocates the modernization of customs procedures as essential for achieving a frictionless Customs Union, perfectly aligning with our commitment to cross-border efficiency and economic growth.
