ALDE underscores that strengthened customs cooperation through this instrument reflects our longstanding vision of eliminating practical trade barriers within the EU.  
ALDE recognizes the fund’s critical role in addressing increasing customs burdens, ensuring alignment with our principles of innovation-driven internal market integration.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s strategic value in reinforcing the Customs Union’s global competitiveness, consistent with our advocacy for trade liberalization and streamlined governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s proposal (COM(2018)0474), emphasizing the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its initial proposal. The resolution, informed by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s report and opinions from the Committees on Budgets, Budgetary Control, and Civil Liberties, Justice, and Home Affairs (A8-0460/2018), instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. It underscored adherence to Treaty provisions (Articles 33, 114, and 207 TFEU) and procedural rules while focusing on safeguarding parliamentary oversight and ensuring alignment in legislative processes.

title: Public procurement strategy package: REPORT on the public procurement strategy package
background: The European Parliament revised public procurement rules in 2014 to modernize practices, but delayed national implementation, uneven SME access, persistent use of lowest-price criteria, and slow digital adoption hindered strategic use of procurement for policy goals. The Parliament will discuss optimizing procurement frameworks to align with EU priorities and address systemic inefficiencies.

stances.stance:
ENF opposes fundamentally the issue's systematic opening of public procurement to third countries, which conflicts with ENF's sovereignty principles by undermining national control over strategic economic sectors.  
ENF rejects the cross-border interoperability mandates as inconsistent with their commitment to localism and national preference in procurement to protect domestic industries.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as safeguarding Member States' rights to independently set award criteria, a cornerstone of ENF's economic sovereignty agenda.  
ENF condemns the issue’s reliance on international trade frameworks like the WTO GPA, which they argue instrumentalizes procurement policy to advance supranational integration over national interests.  
This text fails to address ENF’s demand for explicit clauses permitting preferential treatment of domestic suppliers in line with national industrial capacities.

GREEN_EFA firmly promotes the issue's integration of health and environmental priorities into procurement criteria, perfectly aligning with their commitment to transform food systems through mandatory local sourcing for vulnerable groups.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the condemnation of lowest-price dominance, advocating life-cycle costing to institutionalize the true value of sustainable agriculture and rural job creation.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports cross-border e-procurement interoperability as a corruption deterrent, directly addressing concerns about €2 billion in annual fraud through enhanced transparency tools.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the SME-focused lot division mandates as critical for breaking monopolistic practices in healthcare procurement, ensuring quality-driven outcomes align with social service needs.  
GREEN_EFA commends the issue’s professionalization requirements, which resolve implementation bottlenecks by prioritizing ethical training over bureaucratic compliance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the slow and inconsistent implementation of the 2014 EU public procurement directives, noting that public procurement represents 14% of EU GDP (€2 trillion annually) but faces challenges such as insufficient digitalization, with only four Member States fully digitizing procurement processes by 2016. It highlighted declining competition, with 29% of tenders receiving single bids by 2016 and SMEs securing only 45% of high-value contracts, below their economic contribution. The resolution urged Member States to expedite transposition of the directives, prioritize strategic procurement to advance sustainability, innovation, and social inclusion (criticizing the overreliance on lowest-price criteria in 55% of procedures), and adopt life-cycle costing and MEAT (most economically advantageous tender) criteria. It called for accelerated digitalization, including mandatory e-procurement tools like eForms by 2018, contract registers, and cross-border interoperability, while reducing administrative burdens for SMEs through measures like mandatory lot division and simplified bidding. Internationally, the Parliament stressed the need to address third-country market barriers, noting that over half of global procurement markets remain closed despite €352 billion of EU procurement being open to WTO GPA members, and advocated leveraging trade agreements and the proposed International Procurement Instrument. It emphasized professionalization through national strategies, EU-funded training, and ethical standards, while urging the Commission to finalize guidance on innovation, social procurement, and life-cycle methodologies, and to improve data collection to enhance transparency and combat corruption.

title: Implementation of the Professional Qualifications Directive and the need for reform in professional services: REPORT on the implementation of Directive 2005/36/EC as regards regulation and the need for reform in professional services
background: Disparate national regulations under Directive 2005/36/EC, incomplete Member State compliance with 2013 transparency obligations, and delayed submission of National Action Plans on professional reforms prompted EU institutional review. The Parliament will discuss reconciling single market freedoms with justified national professional regulations to enhance cross-border service provision while safeguarding public interest objectives.

stances.stance:
ENF opposes fundamentally the imposition of Commission coercive powers under Article 59, which undermines national sovereignty in regulating strategic professions.  
ENF rejects the "restrictivity indicator" as a technocratic tool enabling disproportionate sanctions, conflicting with subsidiarity principles enshrined in EU treaties.  
ENF condemns the issue’s harmonization agenda as a nivellement par le bas, destabilizing cultural and economic equilibria protected by national regulations.  
ENF disputes the characterization of national preference as delinquent, asserting member states’ exclusive competence to legislate in the public interest per TFUE jurisprudence.  
ENF opposes proportionality controls on regulated professions, citing the issue’s ideological bias and failure to address degradation risks to service quality and employment.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on transparent and proportionate regulations, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to eliminating barriers in the single market for professional services.  
ALDE entirely advocates the call for full implementation of Directive 2005/36/EC, particularly Article 59’s mutual evaluation framework, as a critical step toward harmonizing justified regulations across Member States.

ALDE applauds the issue’s focus on deregulating unjustified restrictions, which aligns with their stance against economic protectionism and for recognizing qualifications across borders.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the regulation of professional services in the EU, emphasizing the need to balance market efficiency with public interest objectives. It highlighted that services account for 71% of GDP and 68% of employment, yet barriers persist in the single market. The resolution stressed the importance of transparent, non-discriminatory, and proportionate national regulations, referencing over 5,500 regulated professions (22% of the EU labor force) across sectors like healthcare, engineering, and tourism. Key regulatory elements included reserved activities, protected titles, qualification requirements (e.g., education duration, state exams, continuous professional development), and restrictions on corporate structures or joint practice. The Parliament urged full implementation of Directive 2005/36/EC, particularly Article 59, which mandates mutual evaluation of national regulations, and criticized six Member States for failing to submit National Action Plans (NAPs) on regulatory reforms. It called for improved transparency via the Regulated Professions Database, stakeholder consultation in reforms, and regular reviews to address technological and societal changes. The resolution acknowledged the role of digitalization and innovation in reshaping professions but warned of risks to consumers, advocating ethical oversight and equitable access. It urged the Commission to enforce Treaty principles, initiate infringement procedures for disproportionate regulations, and support competitiveness through education, skills development, and harmonized qualification standards. Member States were encouraged to adopt sector-specific reform recommendations and conduct market analyses to enhance global competitiveness.

title: Insurance of motor vehicles: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2009/103/EC of the European Parliament and the Council of 16 September 2009 relating to insurance against civil liability in respect of the use of motor vehicles, and the enforcement of the obligation to ensure against such liability

title: Non-tariff barriers in the Single Market: REPORT on Non-Tariff Barriers in the Single Market
background: Persistent non-tariff barriers, including divergent national regulations and bureaucratic obstacles, continued to impede cross-border trade in the EU Single Market decades after its 1993 establishment, particularly affecting services integration and SME competitiveness. The Parliament will discuss measures to address regulatory fragmentation and administrative burdens hindering the free movement of goods and services.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent non-tariff barriers (NTBs) hindering the single market’s full potential, estimating that eliminating these could yield annual economic gains of €651 billion to €1.1 trillion (5%-8.63% of EU GDP). Key challenges include fragmented VAT regimes, low cross-border public procurement (3.5% of contracts), and barriers for SMEs (only 2% expanding cross-border). The resolution urged swift implementation of the Digital Single Market and Single Market Strategies, emphasizing harmonization, mutual recognition, and streamlined tools like improved Single Points of Contact, SOLVIT, and VAT Mini One-Stop Shop (MOSS). It called for stronger enforcement of existing rules, addressing "gold-plating" in national legislation, and enhancing e-governance (e.g., digital signatures, interoperable systems). Sector-specific measures included reforming services directives, reducing construction and retail barriers, and ensuring affordable cross-border parcel delivery. The Commission was tasked with presenting a comprehensive NTB analysis by 2016, prioritizing infringement procedures for non-compliance, and fostering a compliance culture to unlock the single market’s untapped potential for consumers and businesses.

title: Sign language and professional sign language interpreters: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on sign languages and professional sign language interpreters
background: Persistent disparities in accessibility for deaf and hard-of-hearing citizens across EU member states, coupled with inconsistent recognition of sign languages and insufficient availability of qualified interpreters, have raised concerns regarding compliance with disability rights frameworks and language equality obligations. resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to ensure full accessibility and equal rights for deaf, hard-of-hearing, and deafblind citizens, emphasizing sign language as a fundamental right under EU treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It highlighted that approximately 1 million deaf sign language users and 51 million hard-of-hearing individuals in the EU face systemic barriers, including insufficient access to qualified sign language interpreters, with ratios ranging from 8:1 to 2,500:1 (average 160:1) per user. The resolution stressed the necessity of professional sign language interpretation as a critical accessibility measure or reasonable accommodation in education, employment, healthcare, justice, and public services, noting disparities in TV subtitling (10%-100% coverage) and the lack of standardized interpretation data. It urged Member States to promote sign language learning, ensure bilingual education with qualified interpreters, and adopt minimum accessibility standards for digital and emergency communication. The EU institutions were called to lead by example, providing equal status for sign language interpreters, improving staff accommodations, and implementing projects like INSIGN for real-time sign language services. It also criticized the exclusion of sign language interpretation from the European Disability Card Pilot Project, which hinders mobility, and emphasized the need for inclusive Erasmus+ programs, accessible political processes, and data collection via Eurostat to inform policy. The resolution underscored that accessibility and reasonable accommodation are complementary obligations, with disproportionality claims invalidating denial of access, and affirmed sign languages’ linguistic equality, urging their integration into EU multilingualism policies.

title: Personal protective equipment: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment

The Parliament will discuss regulatory updates to harmonize safety requirements ensuring user protection and effective market functioning.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key amendments to the regulation on personal protective equipment (PPE), including expanding category III to cover equipment protecting against oxygen deficiency (e.g., diving gear), chemicals, biological agents, and radiation/radioactive contamination. It introduced definitions for "demonstration" and "field test," allowing field testing under Articles 7.2–3, and classified connection systems as essential PPE components (Article 3.1.c). Importers and distributors must notify manufacturers and authorities of non-conforming PPE risks, while member states must inform manufacturers if notified bodies cease operations (Article 29.2). Transparent and accessible appeal procedures were mandated (Article 32). The resolution excluded PPE for private use against non-extreme atmospheric conditions, dampness, or water (e.g., oven gloves) unless explicitly marketed as protective, and excluded artisanal products. The Declaration of Conformity was updated to allow digital access alongside paper copies. A new chapter aligned the regulation with upcoming market surveillance rules, and employers’ obligations to provide compliant PPE were clarified (Recital 21). Sporting equipment was included as PPE (Article 2.2b), and linguistic revisions improved clarity (Recitals 11–12). Administrative burdens were tied to safety risks, ensuring proportionality for low-risk private-use PPE.

It called for streamlined IT project management, binding milestones, and increased funding, including €842.8 million (2018 prices) for the 2021-2027 Customs Programme, alongside national resource commitments. The Parliament stressed harmonizing controls to prevent trade distortions like "forum shopping," enhancing SME accessibility, and addressing rising low-value e-commerce imports (growing 10-15% annually). It advocated for improved coordination with international bodies like the WTO and WCO, stronger anti-fraud measures, and potential expansion of the Customs Union to Eastern Partnership countries. resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over widespread unfair trading practices (UTPs) in the EU food supply chain, particularly harming farmers, SMEs, and microenterprises, which constitute 99.1% of the sector. UTPs—including forced payments for non-beneficial services, territorial supply constraints, late payments, and exploitative pricing—stem from power imbalances exacerbated by market concentration, with large retailers and processors leveraging dominance over weaker suppliers. The sector, vital to the EU economy, employs 47 million people, contributes 7% of EU GDP (€1.05 billion market value), and faces crises in dairy, meat, and produce sectors due to unsustainable practices like selling below production costs. Despite voluntary initiatives like the Supply Chain Initiative (SCI), which lacks enforcement, anonymity, and farmer participation, UTPs persist, causing reduced investment, innovation, and food waste while limiting consumer choice. The resolution urges binding EU legislation to prohibit UTPs, enforce fair practices, and establish independent national enforcement bodies with investigatory powers, modeled after the UK Groceries Code Adjudicator, to ensure confidential complaints and penalties. It emphasizes strengthening producer organizations (POs) for collective bargaining, enhancing transparency via price monitoring tools, and revising competition rules to address retailer-owned brands’ anti-competitive risks. Cross-border cooperation and harmonization are critical to prevent forum shopping and ensure equitable market conditions, safeguarding farmers’ viability and consumer interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the need to modernize EU product safety frameworks to address emerging technologies, digitalization, and cross-border e-commerce challenges, emphasizing that the single market for goods generates 25% of EU GDP and 75% of intra-EU trade. The Parliament will discuss the directive’s implementation and areas requiring regulatory enhancement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the need to revise Directive 2009/48/EC on toy safety (TSD) to address critical gaps, particularly in chemical safety, market surveillance, and e-commerce risks. Key issues include the TSD’s chemical provisions, which allow derogations for carcinogenic, mutagenic, or reprotoxic (CMR) substances and maintain age-based distinctions for chemical limits (e.g., toys for children under 36 months), despite evidence of manufacturers circumventing these rules. The resolution calls for eliminating derogations for CMRs, aligning nitrosamine limits with stricter German standards and EN 71-12:2017 (0.5 mg/kg for nitrosamines, 1.0 mg/kg for nitrosatable substances), and removing age distinctions to apply uniform chemical limits. It highlights the fragmentation of chemical regulations across multiple EU laws (e.g., REACH, RoHS), advocating consolidation under the TSD to streamline compliance. Endocrine disruptors and combination effects of chemicals, unaddressed in the current TSD, should be incorporated, reflecting the EU Chemical Strategy for Sustainability. Market surveillance improvements are urged, citing the 2020 EU Safety Gate report where toys accounted for 27% of unsafe product notifications. The resolution supports implementing Regulation 2019/1020 to enhance enforcement, including online marketplaces, and leveraging technologies like blockchain for traceability. E-commerce challenges require aligning the Digital Services Act and revised General Product Safety Directive to hold platforms accountable for removing non-compliant toys. The TSD should be converted into a Regulation to expedite updates and avoid transposition delays, while expanding its scope to cover mechanical risks, allergenic fragrance labeling, and "grey zone" products (non-toys resembling toys). Additional measures include establishing a Pan-European Injury Database, introducing sustainability labels (lifespan, reparability), and addressing cybersecurity risks in connected toys. The resolution emphasizes strict enforcement to protect children, ensure fair competition, and adapt to scientific advancements.

title: Covid-19: EU coordination of health assessments and risk classification and the consequences on Schengen and the single market: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on COVID-19: EU coordination of health assessments and risk classification, and the consequences for Schengen and the single market | RC-B9-0257/2020 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic prompted divergent national responses across EU Member States, including uncoordinated health measures, border controls, and varying risk classifications, disrupting Schengen and the single market while highlighting disparities in ECDC data harmonization. The Parliament will discuss EU-level coordination of health assessments and risk management to address impacts on free movement and market integrity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over fragmented and uncoordinated COVID-19 responses among Member States, emphasizing the need for harmonized measures to safeguard public health, free movement, and the internal market. It stressed the pandemic’s transition to a chronic phase, requiring coordinated risk management, and highlighted disparities in testing capacities, data collection, and recognition of test results across borders. The resolution called for swift adoption of the Commission’s proposal for a color-coded risk map (green, orange, red, grey) based on regional ECDC data, updated weekly, to guide travel restrictions and ensure transparency. It urged Member States to align quarantine periods, testing protocols (including 15-minute rapid tests), and definitions of COVID-19 cases and deaths, while ensuring mutual recognition of tests and minimizing travel disruptions for essential workers. The Parliament advocated for interoperable contact-tracing apps by October 2020, harmonized passenger locator forms compliant with data protection rules, and a European Health Response Mechanism (EHRM) to strengthen crisis preparedness. It highlighted the economic impact of border closures, urging refunds for canceled flights under Regulation (EC) No 261/2004, resilient supply chains for critical goods, and swift implementation of Next Generation EU recovery funds. The resolution emphasized restoring a fully functional Schengen area, avoiding prolonged internal border controls, and protecting consumer rights against scams and unsafe products. It called for a "resilient Europe" strategy to bolster healthcare systems, secure medical supplies, and ensure the internal market’s sustainability, while upholding proportionality, non-discrimination, and fundamental rights in all measures.

The initiative aligns with the Sustainable Products Initiative and aims to reduce waste, enhance resource efficiency, and empower consumers through transparent, sustainable choices.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to transition towards a sustainable single market by enhancing product durability, repairability, and consumer rights, aligning with the European Green Deal and circular economy goals. It emphasized integrating sustainability with competitiveness, urging measures to combat planned obsolescence, including clear pre-contractual information on product lifespan (determined via objective, real-use metrics) and reparability, alongside harmonized labeling schemes like a repair score or environmental performance index. The resolution highlighted that 79% of EU citizens support mandatory repairability for digital devices, while 59% were unaware of the EU’s two-year legal guarantee, underscoring the need for better consumer education. It called for a "right to repair," including free access to repair information, standardized spare parts, reasonable pricing, and incentives for repair over replacement, alongside extending legal guarantees to match product lifespans. The Parliament advocated for stricter market surveillance to ensure compliance with EU standards, particularly for e-commerce, and proposed a digital "product passport" to track sustainability metrics. It urged binding measures to prevent the destruction of reusable goods, promoted second-hand markets through transferred guarantees, and stressed green public procurement to drive demand for sustainable products. Addressing misleading environmental claims ("greenwashing"), the resolution demanded stricter enforcement and transparency, supported by 77% of citizens preferring repair to replacement. Funding via the Single Market Programme and R&D investments were emphasized to support SMEs, innovation, and awareness campaigns, while digital infrastructure’s environmental footprint was flagged for assessment. The Parliament also highlighted the role of sustainable public procurement in reducing supply chain dependencies and fostering climate neutrality, urging ambitious sector-specific criteria and reporting mechanisms.
